title: 'Narco cat' on the run as key piece of evidence for Russian drugs trial is scared off by dogs
text:
A Russian cat slated to serve as the key piece of evidence in an ongoing drug smuggling case has disappeared, local media reported Wednesday, potentially undermining an investigation that centers on the cat’s role as an alleged narco mule for a prison inmate.

The defendant, Eduard Dolgintsev, was accused last year of concocting a scheme by which associates outside the prison would use one of the prison cats to sneak drugs - placed under its collar - into a penal colony in Tula, which is located south of Moscow.

The collar was allegedly loaded with 5.79 grams of hashish and 1.56 grams of amphetamine.

The prosecution’s case rests on the cat, which prosecutors claim can be identified by three secret witnesses.

The cat is also critical to the defense. Mr Dolgintsev’s lawyer, Dmitry Sotnikov, said he intended to run an experiment to find out if the cat was capable of drug running.

Mr Sotnikov wanted to “put a collar on the cat with a load equal to the weight of the narcotics, and then observe how it reacts,” Kommersant quoted him as saying. “Then we would have needed to throw him over the fence and see if he delivered the drugs to his designation.”
